tier.item: This observation is also made in Przepi rkowski & Kup (1997a).
Adam Przepi rkowski (p.c.) notes that the case of bez presents a problem for my claim that
n-words and non-n-words are in complementary distribution. However, I make this claim on
the basis of the distribution of n-words and non-n-words in contexts of local negation, higher
clause negation and non-negative contexts (recall table 1) and no claim is made concerning
their distribution in other environments. Examples like (32) present an interesting case as it
seems that -kolwiek-type NPIs have here a special meaning, comparable to that of strong
NPIs discussed by Kadmon & Landman (1993) and Krifka (1995). In short, the
J. B aszczak, Towards a Binding Analysis of Negative Polarity Items in Polish
This observation is also made in Przepi rkowski & Kup (1997a).

tier.item: adne. I think that the reason for that is the fact that the questions in (44) and (45) are
strongly presuppositional, i.e. it is presupposed that the `addressee' has read some book or
has seen some child. Thus, a full answer, explicitly denying such a presupposition, is more
appropriate in this case, cf. (44') Nie przeczyta em adnej ksi ki (`I didn't read any
book') and (45') Nie widzia em adnego dziecka (`I didn't see any child').
Notice that almost may modify e.g. nothing in there-sentences, cf.
(i) There is almost nothing in the fridge.
Keenan (1987:292) defines almost no as `basic existential determiner'.
Adam Przepi rkowski (p.c.) remarks that it does not make much sense to say that prawie is
bad with czegokolwiek here because the sentence is bad anyway, cf. *Nie zjad
czegokolwiek (`He didn't eat anything'). This is of course true, but the facts are more
complicated. Given what we have said so far about the licensing of non-n-words, one could
expect that since they are licensed by higer clause negation it should be possible to modify
J. B aszczak, Towards a Binding Analysis of Negative Polarity Items in Polish
adne. I think that the reason for that is the fact that the questions in (44) and (45) are
strongly presuppositional, i.e. it is presupposed that the `addressee' has read some book or
has seen some child. Thus, a full answer, explicitly denying such a presupposition, is more
appropriate in this case, cf. (44') Nie przeczyta em adnej ksi ki (`I didn't read any
book') and (45') Nie widzia em adnego dziecka (`I didn't see any child').

(i) There is almost nothing in the fridge.

(i) There is almost nothing in the fridge.
Keenan (1987:292) defines almost no as `basic existential determiner'.
